column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=II
#Text=“ Do n’t you remember me now -- at Mrs. Murrett ’s ? ”
#Text=She threw the question at Darrow across a table of the quiet coffee-room to which , after a vainly prolonged quest for her trunk , he had suggested taking her for a cup of tea .

#Text=In this musty retreat she had removed her dripping hat , hung it on the fender to dry , and stretched herself on tiptoe in front of the round eagle-crowned mirror , above the mantel vases of dyed immortelles , while she ran her fingers comb-wise through her hair .
#Text=The gesture had acted on Darrow ’s numb feelings as the glow of the fire acted on his circulation ; and when he had asked : “ Are n’t your feet wet , too ? ”
#Text=and , after frank inspection of a stout-shod sole , she had answered cheerfully :
#Text=“ No -- luckily I had on my new boots , ”
#Text=he began to feel that human intercourse would still be tolerable if it were always as free from formality .

#Text=The removal of his companion ’s hat , besides provoking this reflection , gave him his first full sight of her face ; and this was so favourable that the name she now pronounced fell on him with a quite disproportionate shock of dismay .
#Text=“ Oh , Mrs. Murrett’s -- was it THERE ? ”

#Text=He remembered her now , of course : remembered her as one of the shadowy sidling presences in the background of that awful house in Chelsea , one of the dumb appendages of the shrieking unescapable Mrs. Murrett , into whose talons he had fallen in the course of his head-long pursuit of Lady Ulrica Crispin .
#Text=Oh , the taste of stale follies !
#Text=How insipid it was , yet how it clung !
#Text=“ I used to pass you on the stairs , ” she reminded him .
#Text=Yes : he had seen her slip by -- he recalled it now -- as he dashed up to the drawing-room in quest of Lady Ulrica .
#Text=The thought made him steal a longer look .
#Text=How could such a face have been merged in the Murrett mob ?
#Text=Its fugitive slanting lines , that lent themselves to all manner of tender tilts and foreshortenings , had the freakish grace of some young head of the Italian comedy .

#Text=The hair stood up from her forehead in a boyish elf-lock , and its colour matched her auburn eyes flecked with black , and the little brown spot on her cheek , between the ear that was meant to have a rose behind it and the chin that should have rested on a ruff .
#Text=When she smiled , the left corner of her mouth went up a little higher than the right ; and her smile began in her eyes and ran down to her lips in two lines of light .
#Text=He had dashed past that to reach Lady Ulrica Crispin !
#Text=“ But of course you would n’t remember me , ” she was saying .
#Text=“ My name is Viner -- Sophy Viner . ”
#Text=Not remember her ?
#Text=But of course he DID !
#Text=He was genuinely sure of it now .
#Text=“ You ’re Mrs. Murrett ’s niece , ” he declared .
#Text=She shook her head .
#Text=“ No ; not even that .
#Text=Only her reader . ”
#Text=“ Her reader ?
#Text=Do you mean to say she ever reads ? ”
#Text=Miss Viner enjoyed his wonder .
#Text=“ Dear , no !
#Text=But I wrote notes , and made up the visiting-book , and walked the dogs , and saw bores for her . ”
#Text=Darrow groaned .
#Text=“ That must have been rather bad ! ”
#Text=“ Yes ; but nothing like as bad as being her niece . ”
#Text=“ That I can well believe .
#Text=I ’m glad to hear , ” he added , “ that you put it all in the past tense . ”
#Text=She seemed to droop a little at the allusion ; then she lifted her chin with a jerk of defiance .
#Text=“ Yes .
#Text=All is at an end between us .
#Text=We ’ve just parted in tears -- but not in silence ! ”
#Text=“ Just parted ?
#Text=Do you mean to say you ’ve been there all this time ? ”
#Text=“ Ever since you used to come there to see Lady Ulrica ?
#Text=Does it seem to you so awfully long ago ? ”
#Text=The unexpectedness of the thrust -- as well as its doubtful taste -- chilled his growing enjoyment of her chatter .

#Text=He had really been getting to like her -- had recovered , under the candid approval of her eye , his usual sense of being a personable young man , with all the privileges pertaining to the state , instead of the anonymous rag of humanity he had felt himself in the crowd on the pier .
#Text=It annoyed him , at that particular moment , to be reminded that naturalness is not always consonant with taste .
#Text=She seemed to guess his thought .
#Text=“ You do n’t like my saying that you came for Lady Ulrica ? ” she asked , leaning over the table to pour herself a second cup of tea .
#Text=He liked her quickness , at any rate .
#Text=“ It ’s better , ” he laughed , “ than your thinking I came for Mrs. Murrett ! ”
#Text=“ Oh , we never thought anybody came for Mrs. Murrett !
#Text=It was always for something else : the music , or the cook -- when there was a good one -- or the other people ; generally ONE of the other people . ”
#Text=“ I see . ”
#Text=She was amusing , and that , in his present mood , was more to his purpose than the exact shade of her taste .
#Text=It was odd , too , to discover suddenly that the blurred tapestry of Mrs. Murrett ’s background had all the while been alive and full of eyes .
#Text=Now , with a pair of them looking into his , he was conscious of a queer reversal of perspective .
#Text=“ Who were the ‘ we ’ ?
#Text=Were you a cloud of witnesses ? ”
#Text=“ There were a good many of us . ”
#Text=She smiled .
#Text=“ Let me see --
#Text=who was there in your time ?
#Text=Mrs. Bolt -- and Mademoiselle -- and Professor Didymus and the Polish Countess .
#Text=Do n’t you remember the Polish Countess ?
#Text=She crystal-gazed , and played accompaniments , and Mrs. Murrett chucked her because Mrs. Didymus accused her of hypnotizing the Professor .
#Text=But of course you do n’t remember .
#Text=We were all invisible to you ; but we could see .
#Text=And we all used to wonder about you -- -- ”
